Here are the extracted sentences that meet the criteria:


None of the sentences in the provided text contain all four required components: a specific molecule name, ID or other identifier, a bioactivity metric, a specific numeric value for that metric, and a unit for that value.

These anti-IL6 antibodies were found to bind to human IL-6 with high binding affinity (e.g., having a KD value less than 10<sup>−8</sup>M, preferably less than 10<sup>−9 </sup>M) and high specificity, e.g., binding to other IL6 family cytokines such as those shown in FIG. 3 with a much lower binding affinity as compared with human IL6.
In some examples, the variants possess similar antigen-binding affinity relative to the reference antibodies described above (e.g., having a K<sub>d </sub>less than 1×10<sup>−8</sup>, preferably less than 1×10 or 1×10<sup>−10 </sup>M).
Typically, specifically binding when used with respect to an antibody refers to an antibody that specifically binds to (“recognizes”) its target(s) with an affinity (KD) value less than 10<sup>−8 </sup>M, e.g., less than 10<sup>−9 </sup>M or 10<sup>−10 </sup>M.

In one embodiment, the equilibrium dissociation constant (KD) value of the anti-IL6 antibodies of the invention is less than 10<sup>−8 </sup>M, particularly less than 10<sup>−9 </sup>M or 10<sup>−10 </sup>M.

Here are the extracted sentences that meet the criteria:


Docetaxel (3 mg/kg each time, once per week) through the tail vein or by i.p injection.
FB704 (20 mg/kg each time, twice a week) or Oxaliplatin (3 mg/kg each time, once a week), or Gemcitabine (80 mg/kg each time, twice per week) through the tail vein or by i.p. injection.
anti-IL6 antibody (20 mg/kg each time, twice a week)
There are no sentences that meet the specified criteria. The text does not contain specific molecule names, bioactivity metrics, numeric values, and units that are required to be extracted.
